Bug.Summery: M5 Run Ant Crashes Under Windows 98
Bug.WithStack:
M5 Build 20020416 Windows 98 Right-click on build.xml Choose Run Ant... Eclipse shows a MS-DOS window for C:\WINDOWS\command.com and then Eclipse does not respond to anything
This does work under Windows NT, Service Pack 6 is it win 98SE ? Yes, it's Windows 98 SE Are you using any Ant task that calls System.exit() ? If so, that happens because the Ant scripts run in the same VM as Eclipse. No ant tasks can be run because the crash occurs right after choosing Run Ant..., before the ant task dialog opens. Could you try this with latest builds (>=20020517) and anotate this bug if the problem still happens or not? If the problem does happen, please add your .metadata/.log file to the bug. Thanks. Haven't heard any news from the reporter neither any other post on the newsgroup about it. Moving to Platform UI (External Tools) for comment or closure.
Bug no longer occurs (Rick Giles, bug reporter). Thanks for the update. Closing PR.

Bug.WithStack:
20020418 i get this when creating ast on the attached file java.lang.IllegalArgumentException at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName.setIdentifier(SimpleName.java (Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.AST.newSimpleName(AST.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:290) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:1428) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:759) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convertToParenthesizedExpression (ASTConverter.java:786) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:680) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:1404) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:762) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:1563) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:750) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:1889) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:1613) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:651) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.buildBodyDeclarations (ASTConverter.java:228) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:168) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:73) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.AST.parseCompilationUnit(AST.java:234) (...) Created attachment 686 the file The problem comes from the expression "result instanceof byte[]". The casting to a byte[] is not properly converted. It should be converted to a Type object, but this is not a possible right operand of a InfixExpression.
I need to talk with Jim, but it seems that we have to introduce a new type of node: InstanceOfExpression. Previously we used an InfixExpression to convert an instanceof expression, but this is not possible anymore. The right operand of an instanceof expression is a referenceType and not an Expression. A new type of node InstanceofExpression has been added. We left the operator INSTANCE_OF on InfixExpression for now, but it is deprecated. Please update your code asap. Fixed and released in HEAD.
Bug.WithOutStack:
20020418 i get this when creating ast on the attached file
(...) Created attachment 686 the file The problem comes from the expression "result instanceof byte[]". The casting to a byte[] is not properly converted. It should be converted to a Type object, but this is not a possible right operand of a InfixExpression.
I need to talk with Jim, but it seems that we have to introduce a new type of node: InstanceOfExpression. Previously we used an InfixExpression to convert an instanceof expression, but this is not possible anymore. The right operand of an instanceof expression is a referenceType and not an Expression. A new type of node InstanceofExpression has been added. We left the operator INSTANCE_OF on InfixExpression for now, but it is deprecated. Please update your code asap. Fixed and released in HEAD.

Bug.Summery: improve editor functionality in Eclipse

Lines.Line: - improve the functionality of the base text editor:
- user-configurable key-bindings
- user-configurable syntax highlighting rules
- provide a mechanism for editor writers to implement completion
- support ctags (this could tie in with completion)
- generalize Java templates into templates which can be used by any
editor
- implement folding (collapsible blocks), and use the markers used
by Emacs and VIM to denote blocks for file formats which don't have
obvious structural elements (i.e. plain text).
- allow on-load/on-save hooks, and supply a default hook to do
conversions of leading spaces to tabs, and vice versa.
Defering for consideration for v3.

Bug.WithStack:
a problem at the moment is that a fair amount of functionality which would be useful outside of a Java context is only available in the Java editor. also, preferences are spread across three or four different preference sections.
suggestions for 3.0:
- in Workbench preferences, create a new section named "Editors", which has shared editor preferences, and editor-specific subsections below it.
- improve the functionality of the base text editor: - user-configurable key-bindings - user-configurable syntax highlighting rules - provide a mechanism for editor writers to implement completion - support ctags (this could tie in with completion) - generalize Java templates into templates which can be used by any editor - implement folding (collapsible blocks), and use the markers used by Emacs and VIM to denote blocks for file formats which don't have obvious structural elements (i.e. plain text). - allow on-load/on-save hooks, and supply a default hook to do conversions of leading spaces to tabs, and vice versa. Defering for consideration for v3.
Note that the current editor framework does have support for code completion, independent of JDT.
Reopen Move to text Related to bug #9355. There is also a problem with expand-tabs-to-spaces functionality, which is present in JDT but missing in all other editors. I personally never use tabs, because text may look ugly when tab settings are different on my customers systems. So i'm forced to use a editor plugin for anything else except Java. Such a basic thing should be in the editors in my opinion. > implement folding ... for file formats which don't have obvious structural elements (i.e. plain text).
related to this is the ability to select a block in a plain text file and collapse it, or collapse everything else but the selected block. (Perhaps this is another enhancement request?) I'm closing this one as there are general text editor preferences now and there are concrete bugs for the other issues like expand-tabs-to-spaces and block selection.

Defering for consideration for v3.
Note that the current editor framework does have support for code completion, independent of JDT.

Bug.Summery: Debug menu items becoming disabled inappropriately

Lines.Line: 1. Create a Java project and set a breakpoint somewhere in the source.
2. Add the Debug Action Set to the Resource Perspective.
3. Begin debugging the project and when the breakpoint is hit, verify that the
Debug drop down menu in the Resource Perspective has the items "Resume",
"Terminate", "Step Into", "Step Over", and "Run to Return" enabled (as they
should be).
4. Switch to the Java perspective, and then immmediately switch back to the
Resource Perspective.

Bug.WithStack:
BUILD: 20020412
STEPS TO REPRODUCE: 1. Create a Java project and set a breakpoint somewhere in the source. 2. Add the Debug Action Set to the Resource Perspective. 3. Begin debugging the project and when the breakpoint is hit, verify that the Debug drop down menu in the Resource Perspective has the items "Resume", "Terminate", "Step Into", "Step Over", and "Run to Return" enabled (as they should be). 4. Switch to the Java perspective, and then immmediately switch back to the Resource Perspective.
RESULT: The previously enabled items in the Debug drop down menu are now disabled when they should still be enabled. Removing the Debug Action Set from the Resource Perspective and then re-adding it will result in the appropriate items being enabled once again. Confirmed same problem in latest code base. This is a known problem (see bug 9082) Workaround: add the debug action set to the java perspective The Debug Action Set also becomes inappropriately disabled in the Java perspective. Fixed as part of the work for bug 16934. Please verify (DarinW). Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
BUILD: 20020412
STEPS TO REPRODUCE: 1. Create a Java project and set a breakpoint somewhere in the source. 2. Add the Debug Action Set to the Resource Perspective. 3. Begin debugging the project and when the breakpoint is hit, verify that the Debug drop down menu in the Resource Perspective has the items "Resume", "Terminate", "Step Into", "Step Over", and "Run to Return" enabled (as they should be). 4. Switch to the Java perspective, and then immmediately switch back to the Resource Perspective.
RESULT: The previously enabled items in the Debug drop down menu are now disabled when they should still be enabled. Removing the Debug Action Set from the Resource Perspective and then re-adding it will result in the appropriate items being enabled once again. Confirmed same problem in latest code base. This is a known problem (see bug 9082) Workaround: add the debug action set to the java perspective The Debug Action Set also becomes inappropriately disabled in the Java perspective. Fixed as part of the work for bug 16934. Please verify (DarinW). Verified.

Bug.Summery: NPE in CVSSyncCompareInput::mouseMove

Lines.Line: 1. Create a folder in a branch with a file in it.
Commit the folder and file to the repository.
2. Create the same folder in HEAD with a different file in it.
Commit the folder and file to the repository.
3. Merge HEAD into the branch or vice-versa (both cases exhibit
the same problem).
4. Notice that when the global 'show pseudo-conflicts' option is
enabled, the editor shows a folder pseudo-conflict and an
incoming file addition. When the global 'show pseudo-conflicts'
option is disabled, neither the folder nor the file is shown.

Bug.WithStack:
1. Create a folder in a branch with a file in it. Commit the folder and file to the repository. 2. Create the same folder in HEAD with a different file in it. Commit the folder and file to the repository. 3. Merge HEAD into the branch or vice-versa (both cases exhibit the same problem). 4. Notice that when the global 'show pseudo-conflicts' option is enabled, the editor shows a folder pseudo-conflict and an incoming file addition. When the global 'show pseudo-conflicts' option is disabled, neither the folder nor the file is shown.
In the merge view hower over the incoming addition, an NPE will occur:

Bug.Summery: Validation of some wizard pages is inconsistent.

Lines.Line: 1. Go to the 'Sample Action Set' page of the Hello,Wizard template wizard.
2. Delete all the characters in the 'Action Class Name' field. You will see the
error message (Template Option "Action Class Name" must be set), and the
Finish button is disabled. That is fine.
3. Append a character to either one of the other two text fields (e.g. the Java
Package Name field). You will see that the error message goes away and
the 'Finish' button is now enabled, even though the 'Action Class Name' field
is still empty.
Please go through all the template pages and list those that exibit this
problem.
Other pages that exhibit this behavior are:
1. Sample MultiEditor page
2. Sample New Wizard page.
3. Sample View main page.
1. Sample MultiEditor page
2. Sample New Wizard page.
3. Sample View main page.
1. On the first page, enter 'com.ibm.etools.xyz' as a project name and click
Next.
2. On the second page all fields have pre-determined values based on what you
entered on page 1. Change the text in the Plug-in runtime library field from
the pre-determined 'xyz.jar' to 'xyzabc.jar'.
3. Click Back.
4. Click Next. You will see that the value that you changed has reverted back
to 'xyz.jar'
Wassim, take a look at this one (you opened it :-).
Fix is in 20020521 build.

Bug.Summery: Hardcoded usage of \t for indent
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020418
While fixing the indent problem for extract method I did a search for \t in JDT UI. The following classes are IMO suspicious regarding their usage of \t
JavaAutoIndentStrategy.java
NLSLine.java NLSRefactoring.java
StubUtility.java
SurroundWithTryCatchRefactoring.java Changed JavaAutoIndentStrategy to use CodeFormatterUtil > 20020430 The strategy of JavaAutoIndentStrategy is to always copy the indent from the current line. Only after a { the indent has to be increased, then the method in CodeFormatterUtil is used.
StubUtility requires users to reformat the generated code.
Moving to Adam for NLS NLSLine is ok - \t is in toString method fixed NLSRefactoring
bounce to Dirk (is SurroundWithTryCatchRefactoring done?) Surround With Try/Cacth refactoring is fixed.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20020418
While fixing the indent problem for extract method I did a search for \t in JDT UI. The following classes are IMO suspicious regarding their usage of \t
JavaAutoIndentStrategy.java
NLSLine.java NLSRefactoring.java
StubUtility.java
SurroundWithTryCatchRefactoring.java Changed JavaAutoIndentStrategy to use CodeFormatterUtil > 20020430 The strategy of JavaAutoIndentStrategy is to always copy the indent from the current line. Only after a { the indent has to be increased, then the method in CodeFormatterUtil is used.
StubUtility requires users to reformat the generated code.
Moving to Adam for NLS NLSLine is ok - \t is in toString method fixed NLSRefactoring
bounce to Dirk (is SurroundWithTryCatchRefactoring done?) Surround With Try/Cacth refactoring is fixed.

Bug.Summery: Method sorting should put methods with less parameters first
Launch configuration XML should be written to file immediately
Bug.WithStack:
The launch configuration history XML isn't written to file until the workbench shuts down. This means that history is lost when the workbench crashes. This may also apply to configurations themselves (I haven't checked).
User-driven XML changes should be written to file immediately. Launch configs are written immediately, histories are not. We should save histories when they change. Fixed. The history is now written on every launchHistoryChanged notification (and NOT on plugin shutdown). Assuming this should be marked fixed for verification. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The launch configuration history XML isn't written to file until the workbench shuts down. This means that history is lost when the workbench crashes. This may also apply to configurations themselves (I haven't checked).
User-driven XML changes should be written to file immediately. Launch configs are written immediately, histories are not. We should save histories when they change. Fixed. The history is now written on every launchHistoryChanged notification (and NOT on plugin shutdown). Assuming this should be marked fixed for verification. Verified.

Bug.Summery: Sync View: local file revision decoration on incoming changes
Bug.WithStack: The sync view shows the local file revision in decorations on incoming changes. This is a bit confusing. We should probably not show the revision in the lbel but instead show them in the editor title area. Fixed. Revision shown in the local editor with the filename. No revision is shown for outgoing deletions and additions.
Bug.WithOutStack: The sync view shows the local file revision in decorations on incoming changes. This is a bit confusing. We should probably not show the revision in the lbel but instead show them in the editor title area. Fixed. Revision shown in the local editor with the filename. No revision is shown for outgoing deletions and additions.

Bug.Summery: Use detail pane for variable value setting
Bug.WithStack:
In VAJ i could set every var to null if i wanted to do that in the debugger When i changed a String var and you wanted to change it to another string i had to set it between quotes and if i want to set it to null i just typed null.
changing vars could be done in the same view as the value is shown in so the detail pane in eclipse. Maybe this can be combined in eclipse also?
But the abillity to set every possible object to null is would already be a big plus. Currently, the way to perform an assignment is to perform an evaluation like "x = null". However, local variable assignment appears broken in the current evaluation support.
Performing assignments to locals should be reflected in local variables when an evaluation is complete. Actually, this is working for me. Defer feature request for entering a value and "saving" to change a variable value. Resolving to later. Use detail pane for variable value saving. Need to determine how we can make this model independant. I.e. sometimes you want to perform an expression eval before setting.
Consider for 3.0 Heads up: Our detail pane for our custom plugin displays a hex dump, etc., and is geared towards display only. *** Bug 38953 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Propose to add a "save" action the details pane. If variable being displayed in the details area supports value modification (IValueModification), then we validate the value, and apply to value. Created attachment 8281 patch to org.eclipse.debug.ui package
New action sets the value of the selected variable using the text entered entered in the details pane. Uses the selected text if any text is selected, otherwise uses everything from the details pane. Darin, please verify. Applied patch. Moved the action to the "Variables" group. Removed the dispose callback since it is not actually called (the action is not contributed - it is created in code, so we would have to dispose it ourselves. However, we do not need to deregister the action, we don't deregister other similar overrides like copy, paste, etc). Verified Does this only work for basic types like int? i tried to change the value for a BigDecimal but that doesn't work ("assign value" is greyed out). It only works for primitives and Strings. We have a feature request to generalize for objects (requires an evaluation & assignment) - bug 56057.
Bug.WithOutStack:
In VAJ i could set every var to null if i wanted to do that in the debugger When i changed a String var and you wanted to change it to another string i had to set it between quotes and if i want to set it to null i just typed null.
changing vars could be done in the same view as the value is shown in so the detail pane in eclipse. Maybe this can be combined in eclipse also?
But the abillity to set every possible object to null is would already be a big plus. Currently, the way to perform an assignment is to perform an evaluation like "x = null". However, local variable assignment appears broken in the current evaluation support.

Bug.Summery: Print format in the detail pane
Bug.WithStack:
Hello, I would suggest the following ; in the detail pane associated to the expression, or variable view in the debug perspective, the printing format is very basic. I would suggest to print out the content of a vector or a dictionary as following instead of all on the same line : for instance we have in memory a vector with the following vales #(aString, anotherLongString, and so on...) We would like to have : [ aString, anotherLongString, .... ] For long lists with complex elements it is very useful... It is also made then in for instance VisualWorks Smalltalk.. Its inspector is for me really a model. regards Xavier This feature is not committed for 2.0

Bug.Summery: Allow to customize the visible search pages

Lines.Line: 0) API to add a new section to the "Customize Perspectice" dialog
Note: without this I would have to add the pages as dummy action sets.
1) API to add things to a section via code
2) API to access the state of each entry
- add a "Customize..." button on the left side of the Search dialog. This opens
a checkbox list with all available search pages.
- eventually add the same checkbox control to the Preferences (Workbench -> Search)
Added feature.
Available in builds > 20020501

Bug.WithStack:
Currently every search page appears in the Search dialog. This should be user-configurable.
The best approach would be to add a "Search Pages" (item) section to the "Customize Perspective" dialog. To do this I would need 0) API to add a new section to the "Customize Perspectice" dialog Note: without this I would have to add the pages as dummy action sets. 1) API to add things to a section via code 2) API to access the state of each entry
Second best approach is a workbench preference where the user can define which the pages that appear in the Search dialog. No workbench support for 2.0. Decided with EG to - add a "Customize..." button on the left side of the Search dialog. This opens a checkbox list with all available search pages. - eventually add the same checkbox control to the Preferences (Workbench -> Search) Added feature. Available in builds > 20020501
Bug.WithOutStack:
Currently every search page appears in the Search dialog. This should be user-configurable.
The best approach would be to add a "Search Pages" (item) section to the "Customize Perspective" dialog. To do this I would need 0) API to add a new section to the "Customize Perspectice" dialog Note: without this I would have to add the pages as dummy action sets. 1) API to add things to a section via code 2) API to access the state of each entry
Second best approach is a workbench preference where the user can define which the pages that appear in the Search dialog. No workbench support for 2.0. Decided with EG to - add a "Customize..." button on the left side of the Search dialog. This opens a checkbox list with all available search pages. - eventually add the same checkbox control to the Preferences (Workbench -> Search) Added feature. Available in builds > 20020501

Bug.Summery: Aggressive activation of Synchronize fast view
Bug.WithStack:
I have my own customized perspective in which I do most VCM-related tasks. If I Synchronize with Repository in this perspective (where the Synchronize view is NOT a fast view), then switch to my Java Perspective, which has the Synchronize view as a fast view, this fast view is always opened, even though it is empty since I just finished synchronizing everything in my custom perspective. Forgot to mention this is under 20020418++ This is how views work in Eclipse - if there is one by the same ID already open in your perspective that's the one you are supposed to get.
I'm not sure how you think we should "guess" you wanted the other one in the other perspective opened. If the Synchronize view had been a 'regular' view as opposed to a fast view, I would agree, but with a fast view, I do not expect that switching from one perspective where the Synchronize view is the active view to another perspective where the Synchronize view is only a fast view should cause the fast view to be expanded.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I have my own customized perspective in which I do most VCM-related tasks. If I Synchronize with Repository in this perspective (where the Synchronize view is NOT a fast view), then switch to my Java Perspective, which has the Synchronize view as a fast view, this fast view is always opened, even though it is empty since I just finished synchronizing everything in my custom perspective. Forgot to mention this is under 20020418++ This is how views work in Eclipse - if there is one by the same ID already open in your perspective that's the one you are supposed to get.
I'm not sure how you think we should "guess" you wanted the other one in the other perspective opened. If the Synchronize view had been a 'regular' view as opposed to a fast view, I would agree, but with a fast view, I do not expect that switching from one perspective where the Synchronize view is the active view to another perspective where the Synchronize view is only a fast view should cause the fast view to be expanded.

</log> Problem cannot be reproduced in base Eclipse platform. Dispose is called more than once. From the stack trace it is diffcult to track down which view caused the problem, all you can see is that it is a TreeViewer. The double delete can be a consequence of calling ContentViewer.setLabelProvider() twice with the same LabelProvider (this bug has occurred before, but is fixed in the base eclipse).
Made the following changes to avoid this problem in JDT code - PackageExplorerPart make setLabelDecorator a no-op. This call is not supported anymore, it was used to add VCM decorations before the 2.0 Decorator solution and it can set the label provider. This change is consistent with Navigator, there this method is now also a no-op.
- StorageLabelProvider protect it against double deletes. There will be no more crashes. The symptoms of a double delete are that icons for non-Java resources inside JARs will not show up.
Suggest to make the call ContentViewer.setLabelProvider() robust against calling it twice with the same LabelProvider. Currently, the label provider is disposed when it is set the second time (see *** below). Moving to Platform UI for consideration.
public void setLabelProvider(IBaseLabelProvider labelProvider) { IBaseLabelProvider oldProvider = this.labelProvider; if (oldProvider != null) { oldProvider.removeListener(this.labelProviderListener); } this.labelProvider = labelProvider; if (labelProvider != null) { labelProvider.addListener(this.labelProviderListener); } refresh();
// Dispose old provider after refresh, so that items never refer to stale images. if (oldProvider != null) { **** oldProvider.dispose(); } } Changed ContentViewer.setLabelProvider to be a no-op if the label provider is the same. The only risk is if clients were relying on this triggering a refresh. But this would only have an effect if they weren't updating the viewer properly in the first place.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20020412 (WSAD install build 20020423-0100)
1. Startup workbench in Java perspective2. Connect to ClearCase LT 3. Shutdown workbench

plug-in: org.eclipse.ui." code="2"> <exception message="null" trace="
"> </exception> </status> </log-entry> </log> Problem cannot be reproduced in base Eclipse platform. Dispose is called more than once. From the stack trace it is diffcult to track down which view caused the problem, all you can see is that it is a TreeViewer. The double delete can be a consequence of calling ContentViewer.setLabelProvider() twice with the same LabelProvider (this bug has occurred before, but is fixed in the base eclipse).
Made the following changes to avoid this problem in JDT code - PackageExplorerPart make setLabelDecorator a no-op. This call is not supported anymore, it was used to add VCM decorations before the 2.0 Decorator solution and it can set the label provider. This change is consistent with Navigator, there this method is now also a no-op.
- StorageLabelProvider protect it against double deletes. There will be no more crashes. The symptoms of a double delete are that icons for non-Java resources inside JARs will not show up.
Suggest to make the call ContentViewer.setLabelProvider() robust against calling it twice with the same LabelProvider. Currently, the label provider is disposed when it is set the second time (see *** below). Moving to Platform UI for consideration.
public void setLabelProvider(IBaseLabelProvider labelProvider) { IBaseLabelProvider oldProvider = this.labelProvider; if (oldProvider != null) { oldProvider.removeListener(this.labelProviderListener); } this.labelProvider = labelProvider; if (labelProvider != null) { labelProvider.addListener(this.labelProviderListener); } refresh();
// Dispose old provider after refresh, so that items never refer to stale images. if (oldProvider != null) { **** oldProvider.dispose(); } } Changed ContentViewer.setLabelProvider to be a no-op if the label provider is the same. The only risk is if clients were relying on this triggering a refresh. But this would only have an effect if they weren't updating the viewer properly in the first place.

Bug.Summery: Old .CLASS Files Are Not Deleted
Bug.WithStack:
When creating a project that does NOT use source folders (and does not use a bin directory for .class files) the .java and .class files are stored together in the Java package structure.
When converting a project to use source folders (and the required bin directory for .class files), the old .class files stored in the Java package structure are NEVER DELETED by Eclipse. This is a bug for Eclipse 1.0 and 2.0.
Since I use WSDD 4.0 (which is built on Eclipse 1.0), I've seen compilation errors due to the fact that the compiler/JDT is using old .class files rather than the new ones in the project's bin directory.
I have not managed to reproduce the compile errors in build 20020416. But since the old .class files should have been deleted this is still a bug for the latest build. This needs to be driven by the UI so as to interact with user. implemented > 20020430

Since I use WSDD 4.0 (which is built on Eclipse 1.0), I've seen compilation errors due to the fact that the compiler/JDT is using old .class files rather than the new ones in the project's bin directory.
I have not managed to reproduce the compile errors in build 20020416. But since the old .class files should have been deleted this is still a bug for the latest build. This needs to be driven by the UI so as to interact with user. implemented > 20020430

Bug.Summery: Add keyword subst. options to "Team -> File Extensions with Known content"
Bug.WithStack:
The preferences panel "Team -> File Extensions with known content" provides for the ability to specify text or binary for files with a given extension.
Currenty content is only "text" or "binary" with text defaulting to -ko keyword substitution (I believe).
A third column that supports the 5 modes of text would be a good enhancement.
"Keywork substitution" none (-ko) keyword expansion (-kkv) keywork compression (-kk) keyword expansion and locker (-kkvl) keywork replacement (-kv)
I know the "Team->Set Keyword Substitution..." exists, but I would like to make the default behavior for new .java files -kkv and other files -ko. I think there is another report on this same subject The text/bin list is global to all providers. I don't know how we would attach CVS specific info to it. This is not possible since the text preference is global to all providers. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The preferences panel "Team -> File Extensions with known content" provides for the ability to specify text or binary for files with a given extension.
Currenty content is only "text" or "binary" with text defaulting to -ko keyword substitution (I believe).
A third column that supports the 5 modes of text would be a good enhancement.
"Keywork substitution" none (-ko) keyword expansion (-kkv) keywork compression (-kk) keyword expansion and locker (-kkvl) keywork replacement (-kv)
I know the "Team->Set Keyword Substitution..." exists, but I would like to make the default behavior for new .java files -kkv and other files -ko. I think there is another report on this same subject The text/bin list is global to all providers. I don't know how we would attach CVS specific info to it. This is not possible since the text preference is global to all providers. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Smoke 20020423: replace from local history wrong indentation

Lines.Line: - load TestCase.java
- edit method runTest
- save
- replace method with latest from local histroy
observe: the method is wrong indented
- MemberEdit assumes that the passed array of lines don't contain line
delimiters. We doc that in the constructor
- CodeFormatterUtil treats empty lines correctly.

Bug.WithStack:
- load TestCase.java - edit method runTest - save - replace method with latest from local histroy observe: the method is wrong indented
IMO the culprit is a change DB did at MemberEdit. The problem has nothing to do with the change in MemberEdit. It is as follows:
the method runTest contains lines with no indentation. As a result the method removeIndentation doesn't remove any indentation. Thus we end up having two indentations.
To fix the problem the method that computes the indent of a code block must deal with empty lines and lines that only contain a new line. The suggested fix is problematic since the member edit and the code formatter util don't know anything about line delimiters. The member edit API takes an array of lines and the initial assumption was that the lines don't contain line delimiters (but it isn't doced). There are helper methods on Strings and TextBuffer to convert a string or a range into an array of lines.
IMO we should fix as follows:
- MemberEdit assumes that the passed array of lines don't contain line delimiters. We doc that in the constructor - CodeFormatterUtil treats empty lines correctly.
Andre what do you think ? Can you pass an array of line which don't contain line delimiters Fixed in build > I20020423

Bug.Summery: TableViewer inconsistent when clicking off of item list
Bug.WithStack:
Test case:
In the breakpoints view, select a breakpoint (OpenBreakpointMarkerAction receives selection changed callback). Click elsewhere in the breakpoints view (NOT on a marker).
The selected breakpoint is deselected and no selection change occurs. The viewers just forward the selection events from SWT. If you set a breakpoint in StructuredViewer.handleSelect, does it get hit? Nope. It doesn't get hit. Looks like an SWT issue then. Fixed > 0501. Rather than change the selection event firing, the motif selection behaviour was changed to mirror the win32 table. Clicking off of a table's list of items no longer clears the current selection. Changed the pr title accordingly.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Test case:
In the breakpoints view, select a breakpoint (OpenBreakpointMarkerAction receives selection changed callback). Click elsewhere in the breakpoints view (NOT on a marker).
The selected breakpoint is deselected and no selection change occurs. The viewers just forward the selection events from SWT. If you set a breakpoint in StructuredViewer.handleSelect, does it get hit? Nope. It doesn't get hit. Looks like an SWT issue then. Fixed > 0501. Rather than change the selection event firing, the motif selection behaviour was changed to mirror the win32 table. Clicking off of a table's list of items no longer clears the current selection. Changed the pr title accordingly.

Bug.Summery: javaw instance left open after running a JUnit test suite
Bug.WithStack:
After running a JUnit test suite using a launch configuration, the javaw instance is left running. The Debug view confirms that the launch doesn't get terminated. The Terminate button on the JUnit view doesn't seem to do anything, and you have to use either the Console or the Debug view to kill the process.
This happens when running in 'run' (as opposed to debug), so it's not an issue with the 'Leave Running' option of JUnit. This is under the 20020423 build. JUnit is owned by JDT UI. Changing component owner. More specifically, tests may cause certain library threads to be instantiated. Without an explicit System.exit(), the jvm will never exit. This should be done when a test suite is complete, unless the option to leave the jvm running is set of course.
Workaround: Launch the test suite using a main() and use the standard jUnit runners. adjusted prio & fixed Excellent.
Bug.WithOutStack:
After running a JUnit test suite using a launch configuration, the javaw instance is left running. The Debug view confirms that the launch doesn't get terminated. The Terminate button on the JUnit view doesn't seem to do anything, and you have to use either the Console or the Debug view to kill the process.
This happens when running in 'run' (as opposed to debug), so it's not an issue with the 'Leave Running' option of JUnit. This is under the 20020423 build. JUnit is owned by JDT UI. Changing component owner. More specifically, tests may cause certain library threads to be instantiated. Without an explicit System.exit(), the jvm will never exit. This should be done when a test suite is complete, unless the option to leave the jvm running is set of course.
Workaround: Launch the test suite using a main() and use the standard jUnit runners. adjusted prio & fixed Excellent.

Bug.Summery: GB18030: Text Editor cannot read files saved in unicode or UTF8 with GB18030 characters

source_code.code: String str = "{Some string with GB18030 chars}";

Lines.Line: 1) Create a text file in Notepad on a GB18030 enabled machine
2) Save the file as unicode, big endian unicode and UTF8.
3) Import all 3 files into Eclipse
4) Set your text font to a GB18030 font
5) Open all 3 - none will have the correct contents
6) Exit eclipse and open the files using Notepad - all will be correct
7) Start Eclipse again
8) Create a new text file with GB18030 characters
9) Save the file
10) Reopen it in Eclipse - content is ??????
11) Exit in Eclipse and open in Notepad - content is ???????

Bug.WithStack:
The Text editor cannot read files with GB18030 characters even if they are saved as unicode or UTF8.
STEPS 1) Create a text file in Notepad on a GB18030 enabled machine 2) Save the file as unicode, big endian unicode and UTF8. 3) Import all 3 files into Eclipse 4) Set your text font to a GB18030 font 5) Open all 3 - none will have the correct contents 6) Exit eclipse and open the files using Notepad - all will be correct 7) Start Eclipse again 8) Create a new text file with GB18030 characters 9) Save the file 10) Reopen it in Eclipse - content is ?????? 11) Exit in Eclipse and open in Notepad - content is ???????
The text editor cannot read or save unicode characters in a GB18030 system Not just a GB18030 issue - the same thing happens in Japanese These are two separate problems: 1. lack of UTF8 or UTF16 support 2. characters lost even when sticking to the filesystem's encoding
What is the filesystem encoding in this case? Is it GB18030? Can you reconstruct the problem using: String str = "{Some string with GB18030 chars}"; byte[] bytes = s.getBytes(); String newStr = new String(bytes); str.equals(newStr)?
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 5399 ***

Bug.Summery: JarPackager support for setting comment on jar
Bug.WithStack:
Would it be possible to support setting a comment on jars? I'm more interested in doing this via the API than the UI. One approach would be to set something in the JarPackageData which the JarWriter can extract and call setComment() on the JarOutputStream. Alternatively, if the output stream were made accessible to subclasses of JarWriter, I could have my own writer handle this. The ability to set a comment is actually at the ZipOutputStream level, so maybe this needs to go even further down. Possible but most likely after 2.0
Simple request - quickly hacked it in. Available in builds > 20020429

Bug.Summery: AbstractTestEditor#init() ignores status of CoreException
Possible bug in compiling inner classes
[Tasks] Selective disabling of compiler or enhanced filtering in task view

source_code.code: // e.g. children now contains CU: Object.java, etc., but not package

Lines.Line: A.java
a.b
AB.java
The TasksFilter assumes that if folder a is checked and included in a working
set all of a's children should be displayed. This works with a resource working
set because a is only checked if all its children are checked in the
ResourceWorkingSetPage. Otherwise only the checked children are placed in the
working set. I.e., if b below a is not checked a is grayed out and A.java is
added instead of a.
This does not work with Java working sets because package a may be included in
the working set but a.b may not. a is checked and a.b is not but the working
set contains a instead of a/A.java.
There are two possible solutions:
1) Change TasksFilter.isEnclosed to test the path of a resource for equality
with a working set element. This means that all leaf elements of folders have
to be included in a working set.
This would change the semantics of the ResourceWorkingSetPage since currently,
checking a folder means the actual folder is placed in the working set vs. all
its children. New children are automatically considered to be included in the
working set.
It would also degrade performance since working sets would contain a
potentially huge number of leaf elements vs. a single folder or project.
Filtering in the resource navigator would be slower.
2) Change JavaWorkingSetPage to mimic the ResourceWorkingSetPage. Leave the UI
the way it is but explicitly include children of packages in the working set
instead of the packages themselves if not all package fragments are checked
(e.g, a is but a.b is not). This would mimic the graying out of a in the
ResourceWorkingSetPage.
I.e., you deselect package a.b, keep package a selected and still see errors
for a.b.
Yes, I confirm this is exactly what is happening.
I have (with the project source directory being WEB-INF/src):
WEB-INF/
src/
com/
jcorporate/
expresso/
X.java
core/
Y.java
security/
Z.java
strongencryption/
A.java
B.java
weakencryption/
C.java
D.java
In this enviornment, because I didn't install the required JAR(s),
strongencryption/*.java all have compilation errors. So, I unchecked the
com.jcorporate.expresso.core.security.strongencryption. But those errors
still show up in the task view, until I uncheck the following as well:
A.java
B.java
weakencryption/
C.java
D.java
In this enviornment, because I didn't install the required JAR(s),
strongencryption/*.java all have compilation errors. So, I unchecked the
com.jcorporate.expresso.core.security.strongencryption. But those errors
still show up in the task view, until I uncheck the following as well:
com.jcorporate.expresso.core.security
com.jcorporate.expresso.core
com.jcorporate.expresso
com.jcorporate
WEB-INF/src
This problem is real so that we should tolerate a minor hack that get's us
there. Should investigate for F1.
Thinking of it again. Option 2) isn't an option. The main reason why we wanted
to have support for Java specific working set is that you can define working
sets with the Java semantics. This is already leveraged for Java specific
searching. We do not want to loose this functionality.
The original idea for handling this problem was to leverage the
IWorkbenchAdapter. Did you ever investigate more into this path? There were
some issues but the path looked promising to me.
This was Nick's latest proposal:
- The working set has the shape as proposed in 2, and contains IJavaElements,
e.g. { package fragment: java.lang }
- This is mapped to the corresponding resource using getAdapter
(IResource.class):
1) Change TasksFilter.isEnclosed to test the path of a resource for equality
with a working set element. This means that all leaf elements of folders have
to be included in a working set.
This would change the semantics of the ResourceWorkingSetPage since currently,
checking a folder means the actual folder is placed in the working set vs. all
its children. New children are automatically considered to be included in the
working set.
It would also degrade performance since working sets would contain a
potentially huge number of leaf elements vs. a single folder or project.
Filtering in the resource navigator would be slower.
2) Change JavaWorkingSetPage to mimic the ResourceWorkingSetPage. Leave the UI
the way it is but explicitly include children of packages in the working set
instead of the packages themselves if not all package fragments are checked
(e.g, a is but a.b is not). This would mimic the graying out of a in the
ResourceWorkingSetPage.
- The working set has the shape as proposed in 2, and contains IJavaElements,
e.g. { package fragment: java.lang }
- This is mapped to the corresponding resource using getAdapter
(IResource.class):

Bug.WithStack:
In large projects, many times there are individual Java files, entire packages and sometimes even entire branches of the source tree that will not compile for one reason or the other. From a particular developer's point of view that may or may not be a problem. However, the (potentially) large numbers of errors that the developer does not care about still clutters up the errors in the task view that he/she really cares about. It would be nice to have a capability to either mark individual Java file(s), or packages or parts of the source-tree to mean "do not compile and/or report errors". Alternatively, filtering of the task view could be enhanced to ignore errors from multiple unrelated Java file (s), or packages (currently, the choice is limited to either the selected resource or ALL errors from the selected project).
In a discussion about this on the Eclipse newsgroup, it was mentioned that the source could be partitioned in a different way to allow current Exlipse functionality to do the filtering. But, in cases where the source tree already exists in a large (open source, say) project, such reorganization is often not possible. Another workaround mentioned was to root each part of the source tree individually, which might work in certain cases, but quickly becomes tedious as the number of branches of the src tree increases. Working sets will address this, but are not yet supported in the TaskList. Moving to Platform-UI Would be nice to have this for 2.0.
*** Bug 12282 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Added working set support to the task view filter dialog. If selected only markers that are in a working set resource will be displayed in the task list. Hi!
I just tested this using the F1 build. It is better in the sense that I can filter based on a working set, and only errors/warnings from that working set are being shown in the task view. But if I edit the working set to uncheck one or more particular packages in the source hierarchy (those that have errors that I can neglect), the errors are still showing up in the Task view.
Shash The problem is a combination of the fact that the org.eclipse.ui.views.tasklist.TasksFilter is resource based and the way working set elements are collected in the Resource- and JavaWorkingSetPage. Given a structure A a A.java a.b AB.java
The TasksFilter assumes that if folder a is checked and included in a working set all of a's children should be displayed. This works with a resource working set because a is only checked if all its children are checked in the ResourceWorkingSetPage. Otherwise only the checked children are placed in the working set. I.e., if b below a is not checked a is grayed out and A.java is added instead of a.
This does not work with Java working sets because package a may be included in the working set but a.b may not. a is checked and a.b is not but the working set contains a instead of a/A.java. There are two possible solutions: 1) Change TasksFilter.isEnclosed to test the path of a resource for equality with a working set element. This means that all leaf elements of folders have to be included in a working set. This would change the semantics of the ResourceWorkingSetPage since currently, checking a folder means the actual folder is placed in the working set vs. all its children. New children are automatically considered to be included in the working set. It would also degrade performance since working sets would contain a potentially huge number of leaf elements vs. a single folder or project. Filtering in the resource navigator would be slower.
2) Change JavaWorkingSetPage to mimic the ResourceWorkingSetPage. Leave the UI the way it is but explicitly include children of packages in the working set instead of the packages themselves if not all package fragments are checked (e.g, a is but a.b is not). This would mimic the graying out of a in the ResourceWorkingSetPage.
There is another option which I don't think we can/should seriously consider. That would be to allow for a custom working set filter in the org.eclipse.ui.workingSet extension point.
I hacked the JavaWorkingSetPage to simply test if a checked element is a package fragment. This is a lesss optimal but quick version of solution 2). It would cause leaf elements to be included even if all packages are selected.
Moving to JDT UI for comment/fix.
See the changed JavaWorkingSetPage.findCheckedElements:
Object[] children= fTreeContentProvider.getChildren(parent); for (int i= 0; i < children.length; i++) { if (fTree.getGrayed(children[i])) findCheckedElements(checkedResources, children[i]); else if (fTree.getChecked(children[i])) { // don't add package fragments directly if ((children[i] instanceof PackageFragment)) findCheckedElements(checkedResources, children[i]); else checkedResources.add(children[i]); } }
Shash, Please confirm that the scenario I describe above matches your scenario. I.e., you deselect package a.b, keep package a selected and still see errors for a.b. Yes, I confirm this is exactly what is happening.
I have (with the project source directory being WEB-INF/src): WEB-INF/ src/ com/ jcorporate/ expresso/ X.java core/ Y.java security/ Z.java strongencryption/ A.java B.java weakencryption/ C.java D.java In this enviornment, because I didn't install the required JAR(s), strongencryption/*.java all have compilation errors. So, I unchecked the com.jcorporate.expresso.core.security.strongencryption. But those errors still show up in the task view, until I uncheck the following as well:
com.jcorporate.expresso.core.security com.jcorporate.expresso.core com.jcorporate.expresso com.jcorporate WEB-INF/src
This problem is real so that we should tolerate a minor hack that get's us there. Should investigate for F1. Thinking of it again. Option 2) isn't an option. The main reason why we wanted to have support for Java specific working set is that you can define working sets with the Java semantics. This is already leveraged for Java specific searching. We do not want to loose this functionality.
The original idea for handling this problem was to leverage the IWorkbenchAdapter. Did you ever investigate more into this path? There were some issues but the path looked promising to me.
This was Nick's latest proposal: - The working set has the shape as proposed in 2, and contains IJavaElements, e.g. { package fragment: java.lang } - This is mapped to the corresponding resource using getAdapter (IResource.class): IAdaptable item = workingSet.getItems()[0]; IResource resource = (IResource) item.getAdapter(IResource.class); // e.g. resource is folder /JCL/src/java/lang - We get the children using IWorkbenchAdapter on the working set item (not the resource): IWorkbenchAdapter a = (IWorbenchAdapter) item.getAdapter (IWorkbenchAdapter.class); Object[] children = a.getChildren(item); // the adapter doesn't wrap the item, so we need to pass it back // e.g. children now contains CU: Object.java, etc., but not package fragment: java.lang.reflect for (int i = ...) { IResource childResource = (IResource) children[i].getAdapter (IResource.class); // e.g. children[i] is the CU for Object.java, childResource is the corresponding IFile }
Reassigning to Chris who is looking at Task view issues, since Knut is away.
Working sets address the original complaint. We still need to address the mapping from packages to resources, but this will have to wait until after 2.0.
Post 2.0. Reopen to investigate Closing bug since original feature has been implemented. Java working set problem wrt. packages is a general issue that does not just apply to the tasks view. Bug 25274 has been opened for this.

Bug.Summery: Setting the accelerator of a menu item gives highlight to tool bar entries

Lines.Line: 1) Open a Java Perspective
2) Close all of the views except Java Packages and the Outline View
3) Move the Java Packages View to the top left side and the outline view to the
bottom left side
4) Open a Java editor
5) Close the editor. The Outline View will be activated (good) but so will it's
only icon - the close button.
Fixed > 1023 as a side effect of fixing (4) in bug 20075.

Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020416 On Linux Motif setting the accelerator of a MenuItem can cause the selection (but not activation) of an entry in a ToolBar. If you then hit return the entry is selected. This can be annoying if the only entry in the ToolBar is the close icon.
The line
OS.XtSetValues (handle, argList, argList.length / 2);
in MenuItem.setAccelerator(int) is the one that will cause the selection of an entry in the tool bar in the active composite.
STEPS 1) Open a Java Perspective 2) Close all of the views except Java Packages and the Outline View 3) Move the Java Packages View to the top left side and the outline view to the bottom left side 4) Open a Java editor 5) Close the editor. The Outline View will be activated (good) but so will it's only icon - the close button. Fixed > 1023 as a side effect of fixing (4) in bug 20075.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20020416 On Linux Motif setting the accelerator of a MenuItem can cause the selection (but not activation) of an entry in a ToolBar. If you then hit return the entry is selected. This can be annoying if the only entry in the ToolBar is the close icon.
The line
OS.XtSetValues (handle, argList, argList.length / 2);
in MenuItem.setAccelerator(int) is the one that will cause the selection of an entry in the tool bar in the active composite.
STEPS 1) Open a Java Perspective 2) Close all of the views except Java Packages and the Outline View 3) Move the Java Packages View to the top left side and the outline view to the bottom left side 4) Open a Java editor 5) Close the editor. The Outline View will be activated (good) but so will it's only icon - the close button. Fixed > 1023 as a side effect of fixing (4) in bug 20075.

Bug.Summery: Deleting many files generates many warnings
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020418
I just deleted a package. It gave me the outgoing change warning for each file in the package. Although I can ignore it, it would be better to just prompt once. This is more tricky than it seems. We have no way of knowing how many files are being deleted. They are given to us one at a time. Either JDT should delete the package folder (instead of each file in the package) or core would have to support an API that allowed the deletion of multiple files. If neither of these is possible, we could support a mode where we prompt once, set a "dontpromptagain" flag and then reset the flag in the resource delta listener. See IWorkspace.delete(IResource[], ...) If JDT and UI are doing multiple individual deletes, then I agree you can't do much about it. closing re: Nick's comments
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20020418
I just deleted a package. It gave me the outgoing change warning for each file in the package. Although I can ignore it, it would be better to just prompt once. This is more tricky than it seems. We have no way of knowing how many files are being deleted. They are given to us one at a time. Either JDT should delete the package folder (instead of each file in the package) or core would have to support an API that allowed the deletion of multiple files. If neither of these is possible, we could support a mode where we prompt once, set a "dontpromptagain" flag and then reset the flag in the resource delta listener. See IWorkspace.delete(IResource[], ...) If JDT and UI are doing multiple individual deletes, then I agree you can't do much about it. closing re: Nick's comments

Bug.Summery: "Add to .cvsignore" enablement inconsistent in sync view
Bug.WithStack:
You can pick an ignored resource (e.g. a .class file) and perform a sync on it.
In the navigator, "Add to .cvsignore" is disabled.
Once in the sync view, "Add to .cvsignore" is enabled for the same class file. You can't sync on an ignored file; Synchronize is disabled for ignored resources. Added safety check to IgnoreAction in the sync view so it is disabled on files that are already ignored, but I'm not clear on how this state happened.
Bug.WithOutStack:
You can pick an ignored resource (e.g. a .class file) and perform a sync on it.
In the navigator, "Add to .cvsignore" is disabled.
Once in the sync view, "Add to .cvsignore" is enabled for the same class file. You can't sync on an ignored file; Synchronize is disabled for ignored resources. Added safety check to IgnoreAction in the sync view so it is disabled on files that are already ignored, but I'm not clear on how this state happened.

Bug.Summery: Maximizing an Editor Should Not Hide Other Editors
Bug.WithStack:
When an editor is maximized, only the editor with focus is available since the other editor tabs are hidden. It's often desirable to be able to maximize the current editor and still be able to switch between other open editors without having to restore the current editor, choose a new editor and maximize the editor once more.
This feature request might be related to: http://dev.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=8869 Which build? The tabs for all editors currently do show when zoomed. This has been in for several builds. You got me. I'm sorry, my fault. The source of the problem was on WSDD (a.k.a Eclipse 1.0), but I was sure it was not in Eclipse 2.0 either.
This PR should be close.

Bug.Summery: JFaceColors hyperlink default clashes with the UI colors
Bug.WithStack:
I modified PDE and Update to use hyperlink color as provided by JFaceColors class. I propose that we change the default value (blue) even though it is the same as with popular browsers. Due to the more subdued artwork in Eclipse, fully saturated blue (0, 0, 255) is too strong and stands up too much.
The default in PDE was 0, 0, 153 (some well known sites like CNN use this color). The darker blue is more in line with the rest of Eclipse.
You may also provide the default for the active hyperlink color (the one shown when the mouse is over the link). PDE/Update forms support active hyperlink color.
I would recommend that the default hyperlink color is picked by the same graphic artists that designed the rest of the UI artwork. Use PDE and Update UI because they use hyperlink the most in the Eclipse SDK. You can ignore Help because its content shows up in a separate window that has a significantly different look. Changed to the darker blue as suggested and added a new active hyperlink color setting which is currently set to full spectrum blue although I am open to other suggestions as to which colour is preferred (i.e. I'll use the same one currently in use by the PDE). Marking closed

Bug.Summery: [runtime] No APIs for obtaining fragments installation directory for a given plugin

Lines.Line: 1. Create IFragmentDescriptor interface with getInstallURL() that would call
PluginFragmentModel.getLocation(). An IPluginDescriptor should have a method
for obtaiing corresponding IFragmentDescriptors.
2. Provide an API to obtain PluginDescriptorModel from IPluginDescriptor.
PDE is in a similar situation whereby it has to deal with fragments that
reference a plug-in even though their content has been merged into the plug-in
in question (for importing binary projects and otherwise handle external plug-
ins).

Bug.WithStack:
My basic problem is obtaining installation directory of fragments for a given plugin without having to cast.
There is already implementation for it: PluginDescriptorModel.getFragments() and PluginFragmentModel.getLocation() methods, but there is no public APIs to use it.
I see two solutions to the problem:
1. Create IFragmentDescriptor interface with getInstallURL() that would call PluginFragmentModel.getLocation(). An IPluginDescriptor should have a method for obtaiing corresponding IFragmentDescriptors.
2. Provide an API to obtain PluginDescriptorModel from IPluginDescriptor. PDE is in a similar situation whereby it has to deal with fragments that reference a plug-in even though their content has been merged into the plug-in in question (for importing binary projects and otherwise handle external plug- ins).
For PDE, solution 2) is more desirable. It is a little unusual, but not inconsistent, because it returns the model object (which is API) but still protects PluginDescriptor that is internal. The only problem may be that PluginDescriptorModel has setters that should really not be called on a running plug-in descriptor model, but I beleive that plug-ins in the registry are marked read only anyway and these calls would result in core exceptions. *** Bug 20499 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Moving to Equinox for consideration. Is this still applicable with the new runtime? Help code does no longer use PluginDescriptorModel. New runtime fixes the problem, since the installation directory for fragments can be obtained as in example: Bundle b = Platform.getBundle("org.eclipse.swt"); Bundle[] f=Platform.getFragments(b); String loc = f[0].getLocation(); URL u = Platform.find(f[0], new Path("")); Platform.asLocalURL(u); And in most cases f.getEntryPaths() can be used and a need for a location avoided. closing. The new runtime addresses this.
Bug.WithOutStack:

1. Create IFragmentDescriptor interface with getInstallURL() that would call PluginFragmentModel.getLocation(). An IPluginDescriptor should have a method for obtaiing corresponding IFragmentDescriptors.
2. Provide an API to obtain PluginDescriptorModel from IPluginDescriptor. PDE is in a similar situation whereby it has to deal with fragments that reference a plug-in even though their content has been merged into the plug-in in question (for importing binary projects and otherwise handle external plug- ins).

The only problem may be that PluginDescriptorModel has setters that should really not be called on a running plug-in descriptor model, but I beleive that plug-ins in the registry are marked read only anyway and these calls would result in core exceptions. *** Bug 20499 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Moving to Equinox for consideration. New runtime fixes the problem, since the installation directory for fragments can be obtained as in example: Bundle b = Platform.getBundle("org.eclipse.swt"); Bundle[] f=Platform.getFragments(b); String loc = f[0].getLocation(); URL u = Platform.find(f[0], new Path("")); Platform.asLocalURL(u); And in most cases f.getEntryPaths() can be used and a need for a location avoided. closing. Bug.Summery: Should ignore old workbench.xml when launching 2.0
Bug.WithStack:
418
When launching a 1.0 workspace with eclipse 2.0, I get repeated notices complaining about errors.
We should detect that the workbench.xml is not 2.0, and ignore it in that case - thus avoiding all of the errors.
The best behavior is to notice that it is not a 2.0 workbench.xml and offer to convert to 2.0 (discard existing) or exit (preserving for 1.0 use) Needed for Friday. Both message.properties and workbench.java were updated to handle incompatible 1.0 workbench saved state. User now has the option to continue with startup by ignoring the saved state or to exit without changing the saved state.

418

Both message.properties and workbench.java were updated to handle incompatible 1.0 workbench saved state. User now has the option to continue with startup by ignoring the saved state or to exit without changing the saved state.

To reproduce this bug:
1. New workspace. 2. Import all plugins using External plugins and fragments 3. Switch to Java perspective. 4. Open type org.eclipse.jface.window.Window 5. In the highlighter, select the static method setExceptionHandler (IExceptionHandler)
The method will not be highlighted. NOTE: All of my plugins were binary. I can only reproduce this with a binary project. highlighter == outliner? yup, step #5 should be:
5. In the outliner, select the static method setExceptionHandler (IExceptionHandler)
Since the selection is working for the other methods in this type I suspect that the source range is not correct. Bug.Summery: [build] Add build.property setting for files that exist in root of install
Bug.WithStack:
Please add a method by which files that should exist in root of install can be copied from a feature, plugin or fragment. Investigate for 2.0 Deferred. Investigate post 2.0.
Reopening for consideration. This addition has only been done for the features:
For the features, new entries in the build.properties have been added. The first one is root The files listed in this property are copied for all the configurations.
The second one is root.$OS.$WS.$ARCH The files listed will only be copied for the configuration described
The format of the value is a comma separated list, where each segment refers to a directory or to a file. See examples below.
Example (part of the build.properties for the platform feature): root=rootfiles,file:../../plugins/org.eclipse.platform/startup.jar root.win32.win32.x86=../../plugins/platform-launcher/bin/win32
rootfiles is located in the platform feature file:../(...) refers to a file that is located outside of the feature

Bug.Summery: Got source lookup dialog for scrapbook when launching Eclipse target

Lines.Line: 1. Scrapbook thread gets suspended when launching another target.
2. It can't find the source when this happens.
- created a scrapbook page
- executed an expression in it which sent some output to the console
- this worked fine
- later, I launched my eclipse target under debug
- the Scrapbook thread came up suspended in ScrapbookMain1.eval
- the Debugger Source Lookup came up for
type 'org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.snippeteditor.ScrapbookMain1'

Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020418
- created a scrapbook page - executed an expression in it which sent some output to the console - this worked fine
- later, I launched my eclipse target under debug - the Scrapbook thread came up suspended in ScrapbookMain1.eval - the Debugger Source Lookup came up for type 'org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.snippeteditor.ScrapbookMain1'
I had never even tried debugging in the scrapbook.
There are two problems here: 1. Scrapbook thread gets suspended when launching another target. 2. It can't find the source when this happens.
In case it's relevant, this is what I had earlier executed in the scrapbook: Properties props = System.getProperties(); for (Iterator i = props.keySet().iterator(); i.hasNext();) { String key = (String) i.next(); Object val = props.get(key); System.out.println(key + ": " + val); } Tried resuming scrapbook thread. It suspended immediately, and again prompted for the source.
Note the name of my scrapbook page is "Scrappy.jpage" and the name of my Eclipse target is "Target", so the scrapbook page appears first in the list of processes. It looks to me like the scrapbook thread is usually suspended, and the Debug view tried to select the first frame in the view on open.
The scrapbook is implemented by launching a VM in debug mode, and performing evaluations. The scrapbook thread is suspended at an invisible breakpoints in a point where evaluations can be performed (thus, resuming the thread causes it to suspend again).
We should not be prompting for source. Perhaps we should be hiding the scrapbook VM all together.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 12783 ***

Bug.Summery: Java Browser doesn't honor number active editors before closing
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020423 integration Window->Preferences->Workbench has a new preference to Close editors automatically. When selected the Number of opened editors before closing can be set. The default is 8. The normal Java perspective uses this value as the number of editors to open before closing the least used editor. However, the Java Browser perspective does not honor the value. When the Close editors automatically option is set, the Java Browser only opens a single editor. Selecting a different file causes the previous one to close. The only way to get more than one editor is to pin the editors open. Unpinning the editors after the desired number of editors is opened allows them to be reused automatically.
The Java Browser should honor the number of opened editors value before starting to close editors prior to opening a new one. This is the intended behaviour of the browsing perspective, which originally comes from VAJ.
Moving to Dani for more comments. Pinning of editors has been removed a while ago so I doubt that you started 20020423. Could you describe how you pin an editor with build 20020423. Maybe you applied the setting on an already open Java Browsing perspective from the time back when Java Browsing itself supported to set the number of open editor. If this value has been set once then it can't be reset with 20020423 because this feature has gone.
Tried the scenario with 20020423 and a new workspace. Then opened the Java Browsing perspective and selected the Number of opened editors (8). ==> works for me. Please test if you youse 20020423 and test it with a new Java Browsing perspective.
Sorry, the comment about pinning of editors is wrong. It now depends on the feature being enabled (which makes sense). However it still works for me. The problem is most likely that "1" is stored along with your old Java Browsing perspective. I guess it works if you trash it and open a new one.

different mechanism.

Bug.Summery: Eclipse starts up with error box
Bug.WithStack:
Yesterday I've installed eclipse-SDK-20020416-win32.zip (M5) by simple extracting upon former version eclipse-SDK-20020321-win32.zip. The former version has been working fine and all settings appeared also in M5, which yesterday had no problems to start up. Yesterday some hours later I installed java 1.4.0. but now I've installed 1.3.1_03 again and eclipse still doesn't start up. Immediately at start up following message box appears (I don't know how to append GIF-image) and that's all what happens.
Eclipse
JVM terminated. Exit code=2 C:\WINDOWS\system32\javaw.exe -classpath C:\Programme\eclipse\startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -application org.eclipse.ui.workbench -ws win32 -endsplash C:\Programme\eclipse\eclipse.exe -endsplash 262450 (or 590358 or..) ... Yesterday some hours later I installed java 1.4.0. but now I've installed 1.3.1_03 again and eclipse still doesn't start up. ...
That was the problem:
Registry key 'Software\JavaSoft\Java Runtime Environment\CurrentVersion' has value '1.4', but '1.3' is required.
Reinstalling 1.3.1_03 over 1.4.0 missed to change this setting.
Solution: change in the registry the value of the corresponding key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\JavaSoft\Java Runtime Environment\CurrentVersion from '1.4' to '1.3'
Bug.WithOutStack:
Yesterday I've installed eclipse-SDK-20020416-win32.zip (M5) by simple extracting upon former version eclipse-SDK-20020321-win32.zip. The former version has been working fine and all settings appeared also in M5, which yesterday had no problems to start up. Yesterday some hours later I installed java 1.4.0. but now I've installed 1.3.1_03 again and eclipse still doesn't start up. Immediately at start up following message box appears (I don't know how to append GIF-image) and that's all what happens.
Eclipse
JVM terminated. Exit code=2 C:\WINDOWS\system32\javaw.exe -classpath C:\Programme\eclipse\startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -application org.eclipse.ui.workbench -ws win32 -endsplash C:\Programme\eclipse\eclipse.exe -endsplash 262450 (or 590358 or..) ... Yesterday some hours later I installed java 1.4.0. but now I've installed 1.3.1_03 again and eclipse still doesn't start up. ...
That was the problem:
Registry key 'Software\JavaSoft\Java Runtime Environment\CurrentVersion' has value '1.4', but '1.3' is required.
Reinstalling 1.3.1_03 over 1.4.0 missed to change this setting.
Solution: change in the registry the value of the corresponding key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\JavaSoft\Java Runtime Environment\CurrentVersion from '1.4' to '1.3'

Bug.Summery: View a file in two different editors
Bug.WithStack:
A colleague of mine asked me to add this. He wishes to be able to have the same file up in two different editor windows. Both windows would receive the edits he would make, but he could leave one window scrolled to a different bit of code within the file.
Jon You can open and view the same file in multiple workbench windows (Windows>New Window) and open the same file again. Yup, that works giving two top-level windows. Further comment from colleague indicate that he'd prefer two editors within the same perspective, both showing the same file. My guess is that this isn't possible currently. Still, the workaround is probably good enough.
Jon
Bug.WithOutStack:
A colleague of mine asked me to add this. He wishes to be able to have the same file up in two different editor windows. Both windows would receive the edits he would make, but he could leave one window scrolled to a different bit of code within the file.
Jon You can open and view the same file in multiple workbench windows (Windows>New Window) and open the same file again. Yup, that works giving two top-level windows. Further comment from colleague indicate that he'd prefer two editors within the same perspective, both showing the same file. My guess is that this isn't possible currently. Still, the workaround is probably good enough.
Jon

Bug.Summery: [Working Sets] Icons for working set types
Bug.WithStack: Since we now have different types of working sets we should be able to distinguish them with an icon (in the working set selection dialog) Defer. Reopen to investigate The working set selection dialog is showing the working set type icon that you see when you create a new working set. I think this is sufficient and allowing for a different icon is not necessary or desirable. It is already fixed: the dialog shows different icons for different working set types.

Bug.Summery: [Contributions] IStatusLineManager.setErrorMessage
Bug.WithStack:
IStatusLineManager.setMessage(String message) doesn't get updated after using IStatusLineManager.setErrorMessage(String message). This is the intended behaviour. The error message overrides the regular message. You need to clear the error message first.
We should clarify the Javadoc on this.
How do I do that? Use: statusLine.setErrorMessage(null); Fixed in 2.1 code stream.
Bug.WithOutStack:
IStatusLineManager.setMessage(String message) doesn't get updated after using IStatusLineManager.setErrorMessage(String message). This is the intended behaviour. The error message overrides the regular message. You need to clear the error message first.
We should clarify the Javadoc on this.
How do I do that? Use: statusLine.setErrorMessage(null); Fixed in 2.1 code stream.

Bug.Summery: Possible concurrency hole when saving index before query
TableViewer works incorrectly with ICellModifier
Bug.WithStack:
When canModify(object, property) and getValue(object, property) methods of the cell modifier are called by TableViewer, 'object' corresponds to one of the elements from viewer's content provider, which is correct. But when modify(object, property, value) method is called, 'object' corresponds to TableItem object. Though I can find out my element with ((TableItem)object).getData(), that is still a bug. The solution is to replace line 257 in TableViewerImpl with the following one:
cellModifier.modify(tableItem.getData(), property, cellEditor.getValue()); This is a known problem which we unfortunately cannot fix as it will break all existing implementors code which know about the problem and do the workaround described.
To do the workaround in a safe way, use: if (element instanceof Item) { element = ((Item) element).getData(); }
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 1938 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
When canModify(object, property) and getValue(object, property) methods of the cell modifier are called by TableViewer, 'object' corresponds to one of the elements from viewer's content provider, which is correct. But when modify(object, property, value) method is called, 'object' corresponds to TableItem object. Though I can find out my element with ((TableItem)object).getData(), that is still a bug. The solution is to replace line 257 in TableViewerImpl with the following one:
cellModifier.modify(tableItem.getData(), property, cellEditor.getValue()); This is a known problem which we unfortunately cannot fix as it will break all existing implementors code which know about the problem and do the workaround described.
To do the workaround in a safe way, use: if (element instanceof Item) { element = ((Item) element).getData(); }
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 1938 ***

Bug.Summery: working set wizards override page title
Bug.WithStack: I create my working set page with MyPage(pageId, title, icon). The title is ignored/overwritten by the working set wiazrds. The working set wizards no longer set the page title *or* description. Implementors of IWorkingSetPage have to do this now.
Bug.WithOutStack: I create my working set page with MyPage(pageId, title, icon). The title is ignored/overwritten by the working set wiazrds. The working set wizards no longer set the page title *or* description. Implementors of IWorkingSetPage have to do this now.

Bug.Summery: clipboards must be disposed
Bug.WithStack:
CopyRepositoryNameAction GenerateDiffFileOperation
create Clipboards and do not dispose() of them the result is a resource leak Fixed. Did a quick search and confirmed that these are the only places that create Clipboard instances. Note that many (>30) other plugins also do not dispose of created clipboards.
Bug.WithOutStack:
CopyRepositoryNameAction GenerateDiffFileOperation
create Clipboards and do not dispose() of them the result is a resource leak Fixed. Did a quick search and confirmed that these are the only places that create Clipboard instances. Note that many (>30) other plugins also do not dispose of created clipboards.

Bug.Summery: NPE due to ResourceWorkingSetFilter

Lines.Line: 1. Set a working set on a window
2. Add a new package in the Java Browsing perspective.
It seems like the new package has to be in a project that is included in the
working set for the NPE to be reproducable.
Fixed by querying the working set elements directly if they have not been
cached by a call to #filter.

Bug.WithStack:
The private method isEnclosed() gets called from API method select(...). This happens when an element is added to a list/table. Unfortunately isEnclosed() accesses a field which is null. The field is only != null during the filter(...) call.
Test Case: 1. Set a working set on a window 2. Add a new package in the Java Browsing perspective. It seems like the new package has to be in a project that is included in the working set for the NPE to be reproducable. Fixed by querying the working set elements directly if they have not been cached by a call to #filter.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The private method isEnclosed() gets called from API method select(...). This happens when an element is added to a list/table. Unfortunately isEnclosed() accesses a field which is null. The field is only != null during the filter(...) call.
Test Case: 1. Set a working set on a window 2. Add a new package in the Java Browsing perspective. It seems like the new package has to be in a project that is included in the working set for the NPE to be reproducable. Fixed by querying the working set elements directly if they have not been cached by a call to #filter.
